attributes.title: Role of Spontaneous Thoughts in Food-based Choice

q1.value: Role of Spontaneous Thoughts in Food-based Choices

q3.value: Recent work suggests that value-based decisions may be made by sampling the contents of memory and accumulating value based on the content of these samples (Shohamy and Shadlen, 2016; Lieder et al., 2018). In a separate line of work, research has found that people can use cognitive regulation strategies to change the value they place on choice options (Hare et al., 2011; Hutcherson et al., 2015; Hutcherson et al., 2018) and that doing so may produce lasting changes in preferences (Boswell et al., 2018). Here, we propose to link these two lines of work, by testing the proposition that cognitive regulation changes the structure by which thoughts are sampled during decision making, and that the specific thoughts sampled determines both what choice is made in the moment, as well as whether or not lasting changes in stimulus value occur.

q4.value:
1) Compared to the natural focus condition, participants instructed to focus on the healthiness of foods (health-condition) will alter their subsequent value:
a)	During active focus, those in the health condition should increase their liking for healthy foods and decrease their liking for unhealthy foods. This may manifest through a change in the weighting/importance of health-related features during subjective appraisals of value. 

b)	These effects of an active focus on healthiness should cause lasting changes in preference, spanning at a minimum of several minutes after the period of active focus. This should be captured by differences in pre- vs. post-focus liking across condition.

2) Compared to the natural focus condition, instructions to focus on the healthiness of foods will alter the pattern of thoughts/reasons that are sampled during the decision-making process:

a) This change may be through either the type or frequency of thoughts related to specific attributes of foods, such as the healthiness or tastiness of foods. 

b) This change may also occur through the ordering of thoughts, rather than their frequency or content, such that those instructed to take a health-focus are more likely to list a health-related reason first but list no more health-related reasons overall. 

c) This change could also occur, not through altering the thought/reasons which arise, but instead alter the appraisal of these reasons. For example, subjects in both conditions may list identical reasons first, but the valence and/or magnitude of this reason differs based on active focus. 

3) The value of thoughts sampled by a participant should predict the value place on foods: 

a) The number (frequency) or valence of reasons should predict food liking in the moment (i.e., during the choice task) 

b) The number (frequency) or valence should predict changes in liking (i.e., the change in rating of foods from pre- to post-intervention)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: No explicit blinding will be used in this study. Participants will be aware of the instructions they are given, although they will not be aware of instructions given to other groups. Since researchers do not interact with participants in the online design, no blinding is required.

question.value:
Mixed-factorial design: 
After consenting to the experiment, participants will complete a brief (7 MCQs) assessment of their English proficiency to assure they can adequately comprehend the experiment. 
Participants will then be shown 20 foods and asked to indicate how much they would like to eat them, ranging from strong dislike to strong like (4-point scale), in order to establish a baseline of liking. 
After this, participants will be shown these same 20 foods again and are asked to list up to four reasons for or against each food. After they have given their reasons for that food, they will be asked if they would like to eat that food, selecting either “yes, I would like to eat it” or “no, I would not like to eat it”. Importantly, during this reason-generating phase, participants are randomly assigned to either a health-focus or natural-focus condition. In the health condition, participants are given a passage to read which discusses the positive benefits of healthy eating, and asks them to consider the information in this passage while providing reasons. In the natural condition, they are shown a passage that discusses a fictitious study which found that optimal food-based choices are made when individuals respond as naturally as possible. Likewise, those in the natural condition are asked to consider this passage while generating reasons, not emphasizing a focus on health and/or any other specific feature of the foods.
After completing the reason generation and choice task for each of the 20 foods, participants will be shown their reasons for each food again and asked to rate the valence of each reason given, from strongly negative to strongly positive. 
After this, each participant will again be shown these 20 foods and asked to report how much they would like to eat each food now. This rating establishes a post-intervention level of liking which can be compared to their baseline liking. Finally, participants are asked to rate the 20 foods they’ve previously been shown for both their healthiness and tastiness on a 5-point scale from very unhealthy/untasty to very healthy/tasty.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to either the health or natural condition, using the embedded Qualtrics randomizer.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited online from MTurk and paid $3.50 USD for their participation. To be eligible for this study, subjects will have to reside in either Canada or the United States. Recruitment will continue until we have reached a sample of 300. All responses will be recorded within Qualtrics and data will not be analyzed until the entire subject pool has been recruited.

q13.value: Prior work (Boswell et al., 2018, PNAS) recruited 242 participants using a similar on-line design, observed small-medium effects of the condition on craving (f=0.18) and medium-large effects of condition on willingness-to-pay (f=0.33). Based on these effect sizes, we have set our sample size at 300 participants, with 150 in each condition (health vs. natural). We expect that after the application of our exclusion criteria, our sample should be roughly 250. Assuming similar-sized effects to those reported in Boswell et al., 2018, this should give us 80-90% power to detect main effects of regulatory condition, depending on the specific test statistic applied.

question.value: The only variable manipulated within this study is the essay/passage they are asked to read. Half of the subjects will be given a passage which discusses the importance and positive benefits of a healthy diet (health condition). The other half will be exposed to a passage which cites a fictitious study claiming that those who make the decisions as naturally as possible (without emphasis on a particular attribute, such as health and/or tastiness) make the best choices (natural condition).

Three outcome measures will be used within this study: pre vs. post-reason liking ratings, decisions made in the choice task, and reason-type/value. Liking ratings will be measured as an ordinal variable with scores ranging from 1 (strong dislike) to 4 (strong like).  Choices will be measured as a binary variable, with 1 corresponding to accepting the food (yes, I would like to eat this food) and 0 corresponding to rejecting the food. Reasons will be coded by category (e.g., related to taste, related to health, other) to determine whether condition alters the frequency or order in which different reasons are generated. 
Health and taste ratings of each food, reasons given, pre-reason liking and the condition the participant is in will all be used as predictors of post-reason liking and changes pre-post in liking.

Reason-type may be combined into an index to assess the average number or frequency of health or taste reasons. This may be done either for each participant or for each food. These kinds of indices will be exploratory in nature.

Changes in liking (Post-liking - Pre-liking) will be calculated as a mean for each subject. A mean change in liking will be calculated overall (across all 20 foods), as well as in subsets of the foods. A mean will be calculated for each subject across only tasty foods, only healthy foods, etc. In addition, the change for each food will be calculated for use in mixed-effect regressions.

1) To test the hypothesis that instructing participants to focus on the healthiness of foods, between-group analyses will be conducted:

a) To determine if condition has an effect on value during active-focus, mean acceptance of foods during the choice task will be calculated for each subject, with accepting the food being coded as 1, and rejecting the food coded as 0. These subject-level means will be calculated across all foods, as well as for only healthy and tasty foods separately. Between-group t-tests will then be used to determine if conditions differ in their average acceptance of healthy foods, tasty foods, etc. 

b) To determine if this active focus results in lasting alterations to preference, mean changes in liking (post-focus rating – pre-focus rating) will be calculated for each subject, both overall, and by food type (healthy foods, tasty foods, etc). Between-group t-tests will then be conducted to determine if conditions significantly differ in their mean change in liking, either overall, or as a function of food-type. 

2) To test the hypothesis that condition alters the use of health attributes to construct liking, we will run linear regressions to predict pre- and post-liking ratings. We will assess whether health ratings or taste ratings predict liking, and whether the strength of this effect is modulated from pre- to post-, either overall or as a function of condition.
 
3) To test the hypothesis that condition has an effect on reasons generated, we will conduct several analyses. First, we will use between-group t-tests to examine whether condition influences the average number and proportion of different reason-types (e.g., taste-related reasons, health-related reasons). We will also conduct analyses to assess whether the order in which reasons are listed in changes.

4) To determine whether the number or valence of reasons generated is correlated with a subject’s change in liking, we will test if the beta-coefficients on these terms differs significantly across condition in the full mixed-effect linear regression model. 

5) To assess if the number of health-related reasons given is correlated with changes in liking, we will measure the correlation between the number of health-related reasons generated and the increase in liking towards healthy foods and/or subsequent decline in liking towards tasty foods.
6) To assess if the reasons subjects generated predict changes in liking above-and-beyond the effects of other known predictors (health-ratings, taste-ratings, etc), mixed-effect linear regression (MELR) will be used both incorporating only these known predictors (reduced model) and incorporating reasons data as well (full model). Significant reductions in BIC or divergence will be used to determine if this hypothesis is true.

q20.value: Natural language processing (NLP) approaches will be explored in order to automatize the classification of reason data into various categories. Prior, unpublished work within our laboratory will be used as a potential corpus to use in training this classification system. If this fails, reasons will be hand-coded to determine if this reason is categorized as taste-based, health-based, or related to a different attribute of the food.

q22.value:
RTs which are extremely fast and/or slow ( < 0.2 s or  > 5 s) will be excluded and replaced as NA. Subjects which habitually show the same response (more than 90% of responses at same liking rating), will be excluded. 

Finally, subjects who show duplicated IP addresses (IP addresses we have already received submissions from) will also be excluded, to assure participants did not complete the study multiple times.

attributes.title: Offloading - Related and Unrelated Lists Replication

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: We will also analyze the false recall of related critical lures for the categorized list participants. We expect to replicate our previous work showing that offloading increases false recall of related words.

sample.value: The number of observations collected will be N = 80, same as the previous experiment that this one is replicating.

analyses.value:
We will focus our analyses on the final block of trials, where participants do not have access to their written lists.

We will use a mixed ANOVA (BS: shuffled vs unshuffled; WS: offload vs no offload) to analyze the recall of the items. We will also use a mixed effects logistic regression to predict the effect of offloading and list type on recall.

outliers.value:
We will remove participants who do not follow the rules (e.g. used the wrong list of words), did not complete the experiment, or switched to a different window during the experiment (as indicated by browser interaction data). These participants will be replaced.

We will consider recalled words that were not presented as intrusions and will not include them in the analysis.

dependent.value: Key dependent variable: recall rate for the presented items.

conditions.value:
We have a within-subjects independent variable with two levels, Offload and No Offload. For all participants, half of the words studied will be marked in a colour representing No Offload (i.e., participants do not expect to have access to the words they had written down during encoding); the other half will be Offload (i.e., participants expect to have access to the words written down during encoding). 

We also have a between-subjects independent variable with two levels: categorized lists (unshuffled) and shuffled lists. In the unshuffled list condition, within each block, words presented in the same color will be from a categorized list that reliably produces false recall of a critical lure (e.g. bed, rest, awake; sleep). In the shuffled list condition, the words will be from pre-shuffled lists derived from the same words making up the categorized lists.

hypothesis.value: Does the effect of cognitive offloading diminish with categorized lists?

attributes.title: Surveying the landscape of CIHR-funded research data sharing practices: An analysis of the published literature
attributes.description: This study will aim to accomplish two specific goals by assessing the availability of health sciences research datasets funded by the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR). The first goal will be to understand the Canadian data sharing landscape by reviewing how and where Canadian health sciences researchers share their data. The second goal will be to compare Canadian researchers’ current data sharing practices to the Tri-agency’s proposed framework for research data management and sharing. The information gathered from this study will be used to identify gaps within the Canadian data sharing landscape, and help inform the future development of data policy, infrastructure and research data management support by highlighting the key challenges and opportunities with respect to data sharing in a Canadian context.

summary.value:
INTRODUCTION: This study will aim to accomplish two specific goals by assessing the availability of health sciences research datasets funded by the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR). The first goal will be to understand the Canadian data sharing landscape by reviewing how and where Canadian health sciences researchers share their data. The second goal will be to compare Canadian researchers’ current data sharing practices to the Tri-agency’s proposed framework for research data management and sharing. The information gathered from this study will be used to identify gaps within the Canadian data sharing landscape, and help inform the future development of data policy, infrastructure and research data management support by highlighting the key challenges and opportunities with respect to data sharing in a Canadian context.

METHODS: This study will identify all CIHR-funded articles that have indicated whether or not they have shared the research data underlying their published results using PubMed and PubMed Central’s (PMC) dataset search filters. Using PubMed Central, this study will identify CIHR-funded articles that include a data availability statement or include data citations. An additional set of articles will be identified in PubMed using the data filter, which locates articles that directly link to National Institutes of Health-specific or external data repositories. These respective searches will be combined with CIHR-related terms, including both its English and French pronunciation, in the grants information field of both databases. It is anticipated that this search will retrieve close to 5000 articles across both databases.

Once all articles are identified, they will be cross-examined to determine the number of duplicates to account for overlap in both databases. All duplicates will be removed, and specific metadata fields will be extracted from each database. First, the Open Access Subset API -- which allows for the full text of an article to be extracted under a Creative Commons license. If articles are not available via the Open Access Subset, they will be extracted using the metadata available in PMC. The remaining articles that are not available in PMC will have a limited set of metadata extracted from the MEDLINE/PubMed dataset. All data will be compiled into a raw dataset which will be saved in a preservation-friendly .csv format and stored on secure University of Saskatchewan servers.

DATA ANALYSIS: The raw dataset described above will be used to analyze each individual article to identify where, how, and if any research data was shared. Information that will be collected from each article to help understand the nature of data sharing will include: the institution of the corresponding author or the author of the article who was funded by the CIHR; location of the data being shared; instructions accompanying the data sharing statement; date of publication; journal title; Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) major topics used to describe the article; keywords provided by the author and/or publisher; and the funding type. 

Each data sharing instance will also be assessed using the Tri-agency framework for data management and sharing. These variables include: 1) adherence to standards, 2) data collection and storage, 3) metadata, 4) preservation, retention, and sharing, and 5) timeliness. Each article will be reviewed according to this framework to ascertain whether or not it meets the proposed Tri-agency guidelines.

other.value: Additional variables collected will include Social Dominance Orientation, Political Ideology, Political Party Identification

sample.value:
We will be collecting data on a series of 440 hypothetical political policies. Crucially, given this is more questions than any one participant can reasonably answer, we will have participants complete a random selection of 30 of the 440 hypothetical policies.

This approach to data collection allows for a data set that is "Massively Missing Completely at Random" (MMCAR; Revelle, Condon, Wilt, French, Brown, and Elleman, 2016). 

Based on the results of a series of power analysis simulations using the simr package (Green and MacLeod, 2016) in R (R Core Team, 2019), we will be collecting data on 440 hypothetical political policies from 1,500 individual participants, who each respond to 30 policies. This approach will allow for 100 observations per policy and greater than 80% power (alpha = .05) to detect standardized regression coefficients as small as .05.

analyses.value:
We will be primarily taking a crossed-factors multilevel model approach to analyzing these data.

Primarily, we will code each of the policies on a number of relevant dimensions, all coded as either 0 (No) and 1 (Yes). For example, we will code each policy on whether it helps the poor, hurts the poor, helps the rich, hurts the rich, increases inequality, or decreases inequality.

Following this, we will run a series of cross-factors multilevel models to explore the relative strength of each policy characteristic at predicting both binary hypothetical voting ("Would you vote for this policy, yes (1) or no (0)?") as well as 7-point Likert responses indicating the degree of policy support (1- Would Strongly Oppose to 7 - Would Strongly Support). 

Additionally, in analyses that take into account political ideology will be determined by two questions. First, participants will answer "Do you most closely identify as: Republican, Democrat, Independent, and Other." If a participant chooses "Other" or "Independent," they will then be asked "If you had to choose one, today, which do you more closely identify with: Republican or Democrat." All participants who choose Republican or Democrat on either the first or second question will be coded as such. 

For some analyses, we will code the policies slightly differently. We will code whether a policy increases, decreases, or does not effect the wealth of rich and poor as -1 for decreases, 0 for no change, and 1 for increases. We will also do this for change in inequality (-1 reduces inequality, 0 no change, 1 increases inequality).

We will test the proposed hypotheses using the following models (all variables will be standardized):

lmer(support~help_poor+hurt_poor+help_rich+hurt_rich+dec_ineq+inc_ineq + (1 | pid) + (1 | distribution), data=data, na.action="na.omit")

lmer(support~help_poor+hurt_poor+help_rich+hurt_rich+dec_ineq+inc_ineq + repub + (help_poorz*repub) + (hurt_poorz*repub) + (help_richz*repub) + (hurt_richz*repub) +(dec_ineqz*repub) + (inc_ineqz*repub) + (1 | pid) + (1 | distribution), data=data, na.action="na.omit")

lmer(support~change_poor+change_rich+change_ineq+(1 | pid) + (1 | distribution), data = long, na.action = "na.omit")

lmer(support~change_poor+change_rich+change_ineq+repub+(change_poor*repub) + (change_rich*repub) + (change_ineq*repub)+(1 | pid) + (1 | distribution), data = long, na.action = "na.omit")

Within each model, the crossed level two nesting variables are PID and Distribution, which indicate which participant each response came from, and which distribution the participant was responding to.

outliers.value: The only participants who will be excluded are ones who fail our attention check (e.g., "Please select "Strongly Disagree" for this question").

dependent.value:
Binary policy support ("Would you vote for this policy?" Yes/No) as well as a seven-point likert question of policy support ("How strongly would you support this policy?" from 1 (Would Strongly Oppose) to 7 (Would Strongly Support)).

Our primary DV will be the the seven-point likert questions of policy support.

conditions.value: There will be no experimental conditions in this study. However, we will be utilizing a planned missingness design; see the section on "Sample Size" for a detailed description of this procedure.

hypothesis.value:
The main purpose of this research is to develop and explore a new methodological framework with which we can understand what motivates decision making surrounding intergroup political policies. As detailed in the analysis section, our primary aim is to test our specified models. While this study is primarily exploratory, pilot data has informed three hypotheses:

1. The relationship between policy support and helping the rich will be moderated by political ideology (Republican versus Democrat).

2. The negative relationship between policy support and whether or not a policy hurts the rich will be weaker among Republicans versus Democrats.

3. The positive relationship between policy support and whether or not a policy decreases inequality will be weaker among Republicans versus Democrats.

name.value: Iterative decision-making procedures (Voting: Group and Vote composition)

other.value:
These are additional measures we are collecting for exploration and do not have strong hypotheses on: 
What decision rule should the group use if they are to decide again? (Options: decision rule pre-specified in condition (here, voting), letting the kids who want popcorn get their way, letting the kids who want chips get their way, and deciding another way with an open response).

sample.value: We plan to collect 50 participants per condition. We will aim to recruit 200 total participants.

analyses.value:
T1/T2/T3 fairness evaluations: At each time point, we will compute participants’ mean fairness evaluation and compare participants’ response across the conditions. We will construct a generalized linear model with fairness evaluation as the outcome variable and Vote composition (Fixed vs. Mixed) and Group (Groups present vs. No Groups present) as predictor variables. We will additionally test whether the interaction term (Vote composition x Group) explains additional variance. We predict that voting will be perceived as equally fair across conditions at T1 (however, one possibility is that voting will be perceived as less fair in the Groups present conditions at T1, as the proportions in the class may lead participants to view voting as less fair system; we will test for this possibility). and T2 but differ at T3. Specifically, we predict that there will be a main effect of Vote composition: across both Groups present and No Group, participants in the Fixed conditions will view voting as less fair at T3 than participants in the Mixed conditions. We will additionally examine whether there is a main effect of Group or an Interaction between Group and Vote composition. One possibility is that the presence of groups will make the fixedness of preferences more salient. If this is the case, then we expect there to be a difference between the Fixed conditions, such that there is a greater decrease in perceived fairness in the Fixed Groups present condition than in the Fixed No Groups present condition. 

Difference from T1 to T2: As described above, we will compute the difference between participants’ fairness evaluations at T1 and T2 (T2-T1). We will compare this difference score across the four conditions, again using a generalized linear model with difference score as the outcome and Vote composition and Group as predictor variables. 

Difference from T2 to T3: We will compute the difference between participants’ fairness evaluations at T2 and T3 (T3-T2). We will compare this difference score across the conditions in the same way as described above. We predict that there will be a main effect of Voting composition—that this difference score will be greater in the Fixed conditions than in the Mixed conditions. We also expect that there will be a main effect of Group, such that this difference score will be larger in the Fixed Group condition than in the Fixed No Group condition. 

How likely is the decision rule to yield the same outcome: We will compare how likely participants think the decision rule is to yield the same outcome (popcorn) across the two conditions by constructing a generalized linear model with perceived voting outcome as the outcome variable and Voting composition and Group as predictor variables. We predict that there will be a main effect of Voting composition such that participants will think the procedure is more likely to yield popcorn in the Fixed conditions than in the Mixed conditions.  

Perceived outcome ~ Perceived change in fairness: To examine whether participants’ fairness evaluations relate to how likely they think the procedure is to yield a fixed outcome, we will construct a generalized linear model predicting T3-T2 difference score by perceived outcome, Voting composition, and Group (we will examine whether the interaction between perceived outcome and Voting composition explains additional variance). We predict that the more likely participants are to think that voting will yield popcorn as the outcome, the more participants’ fairness evaluation will decrease from T2 to T3. We predict that this relation will be stronger in the Fixed conditions (though likely present in both conditions) and strongest in the Fixed Group condition. 

Desire difference: We will compute a difference score between participants’ judgments of the two class member’s desires to vote again. We will compare this difference score across the conditions (using a generalized linear model with difference score as the outcome and Voting composition and Group as predictors). We predict that participants in the Fixed conditions will think that an individual who has consistently won will prefer to vote again compared to one who has consistently lost. In contrast, we predict that participants in the Mixed conditions will think that two individuals in the class will want to vote at equal rates. 

Difference in desire ~ Perceived change in fairness: To examine whether participants’ judgments of the individuals’ desires relates to their perception of fairness, we will construct a generalized linear model predicting difference in desires by change in perceived fairness (T3-T2), Voting composition, and Group (and we will consider whether the interaction terms explain additional variance). We predict that the more participants think the desires of the two individuals differ, the more they will decrease in their perception of fairness from T2 to T3. We expect this relation to be present especially in the Fixed conditions (particularly in the Fixed Group condition). 

Difference in desire ~ Perceived outcome: Finally, we will examine whether participants’ judgments of the individuals’ desires relates to how likely they think the voting procedure is to yield popcorn as the outcome. To do so, we will again construct a generalized linear model with difference in group member’s desires (majority-minority) as the outcome variable and perceived voting outcome (% yielding popcorn), Voting composition, and Group as predictor variables (we will consider whether the interaction terms explain additional variance). We predict that the more likely participants think the procedure is to yield popcorn, the more they will think the individuals’ desires to vote differ, but we only expect this relation in the Fixed conditions and not in the Mixed conditions.

dependent.value:
The key DVs are fairness evaluations at three different time points: T1 (before a decision is made), T2 (after the first decision is made), and T3 (after three decisions are made). Fairness evaluations will be measured on a 1-7 Likert scale (extremely unfair to extremely fair). We will also ask participants how likely they believe the decision rule (voting) is to yield the same outcome (i.e., the winning option: popcorn) if used again (scale from 1 to 100). 

We will calculate difference scores between T1 & T2 (to check that participants’ responses are not merely due to viewing the rule in action; here, we expect there to be no difference) and between T2 & T3. 

We will ask participants to evaluate how likely or unlikely it will be that specific characters in the paradigm will want to use the decision rule again.

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to 1 of 4 conditions in this 2(Group: Groups present or No Groups present) x 2(Vote composition: Fixed preferences or Mixed preferences) design.

hypothesis.value:
This study examines how adults think about the functionality of voting as a decision-rule and whether voting is considered more or less fair depending on the composition of the majority group. Specifically, we examine adults’ fairness evaluations when votes are or are not won along group lines.  

In previous studies, we introduced adults to a classroom containing five groups of kids who were split into two social groups—Blues and Greens. We told participants that the class would vote to decide what to eat for snack time. Participants then saw the class vote across several iterations (i.e., several different days). We examined whether adults considered the composition of the winning group when evaluating the fairness of the procedure. In a first study, we demonstrated that adults viewed iterated votes as increasingly less fair if the majority group was consistently comprised of individuals from only one social group (e.g., there are more blues, blues always vote for one option, and thus blues always win). In a second study, we demonstrated that the composition of the winning group mattered. Here, the individuals that comprised the winning majority group varied from day to day such that the winning group at times contains individuals from both social groups (e.g., the winning group at times contains both blues and greens). In this case, adults’ viewed voting as consistently fair, even after iterated trials. These studies demonstrate that the composition of the winning group influences how fair adults judge voting to be. However, it is unclear from these results if adults opposition stems from the same social group repeatedly winning, or the same individuals repeatedly winning. Thus, in this next study, we examine whether or not the presence of groups, specifically, drives this effect. That is, do participants still consider it unfair for the same individuals to consistently vote for one option and consistently get their way even if they are NOT part of a unified social group?

In the present study, participants will again see a brief scenario about a classroom of five kids who are making a decision about whether to eat popcorn or chips for snack time. This is a 2x2 design in which we will manipulate whether there is or is not group membership (2: Groups present or No Groups present) and the majority composition (2: Mixed preferences or Fixed preferences). All participants will see the class vote across three iterations and will be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions. 

Groups present or No Groups present. In the Groups present  conditions, participants will see two primary groups, as in the previous studies. Participants will be told that there are two kinds of kids in the class: Blue kids and Green kids. One of these groups comprises the majority of the class (3 out of 5 kids) and the other comprises the minority of the class (2 out of 5 kids). Which color group is the majority or minority will be counterbalanced across participants. In the No Groups present condition, participants will see a classroom of five individual characters who do not belong to social groups (i.e., each individual is a different color and there is no mention of social groups).
 
Fixed preferences. 
In the Fixed preferences conditions, the individuals that comprise the winning majority group do not change across trials. That is, individuals vote for the same options across iterations and the same individuals always win. 
Groups present. In the Groups present condition with Fixed preferences, the three individuals that comprise the majority social group (e.g., the Greens) always vote for one option (e.g., popcorn) and always win, whereas the two individuals that comprise the minority social group (e.g., the Blues) always vote for the other option (e.g., chips) and always lose.  
No Groups present. In the No Groups present condition with Fixed preferences, three individuals (e.g., Pink, Blue, Purple) always vote for the one option (e.g., popcorn) and always win, whereas the other two individuals (e.g., Green, Yellow) always vote for the other option (e.g., chips) and always lose. Importantly, the same individuals always win but these individuals are not part of a social group. 

Mixed preferences. 
In the Mixed preferences conditions, the individuals that comprise the winning majority group vary from trial to trial. That is, individuals vote for different options across iterations and different individuals win across different iterations. 
Groups present. In the Groups present condition with Mixed preferences, the composition of winning votes is not anchored to group membership. Therefore, individuals from both the Majority and Minority Groups at times vote for the winning option (i.e., popcorn) across the iterations. 
No Groups present. In the No Groups present condition with Mixed preferences, the composition of winning votes changes from trial to trial. That is, different individuals (e.g., Pink, Blue, Purple on Iteration 1 and Green, Yellow, Blue on Iteration 2) vote for the winning option (i.e., popcorn) on different votes. 

We hypothesize that there will be a main effect of Vote Composition (Mixed versus Fixed preferences)—that across both Groups present and No Groups present conditions, voting will be considered more fair when preferences are mixed. That is, we expect to replicate results from the previous experiments and also expand the result by demonstrating that fairness evaluations are not necessarily tied to group membership. Instead, we expect fairness evaluations to have to do with the iteration of who does or does not get their way. 

Although we expect that the main effect of Vote Composition will be present in both Groups present and No Groups present conditions, we suspect that the main effect may be stronger in the Groups present condition than the No Groups present condition. Group membership may make the fixedness of preferences with iteration more salient to participants, or seem particularly unfair, perhaps even resulting in an interaction effect.

That is, different individuals (e.g., Pink, Blue, Purple on Iteration 1 and Green, Yellow, Blue on Iteration 2) vote for the winning option (i.e., popcorn) on different votes. 

We hypothesize that there will be a main effect of Vote Composition (Mixed versus Fixed preferences)—that across both Groups present and No Groups present conditions, voting will be considered more fair when preferences are mixed. That is, we expect to replicate results from the previous experiments and also expand the result by demonstrating that fairness evaluations are not necessarily tied to group membership. Instead, we expect fairness evaluations to have to do with the iteration of who does or does not get their way. 

Although we expect that the main effect of Vote Composition will be present in both Groups present and No Groups present conditions, we suspect that the main effect may be stronger in the Groups present condition than the No Groups present condition. Group membership may make the fixedness of preferences with iteration more salient to participants, or seem particularly unfair, perhaps even resulting in an interaction effect.

question1a.value:
H1a: Participants in the threat condition will have lower responses time (RT) at the Stroop task than participants in the control condition.

H2a: Political orientation may moderate H1 : People that are more right-wing will have lower responses time at the Stroop task in the threat (vs. control) condition than people higher in left-wing political orientation. 
H2b:  Political orientation may moderate H2 : People that are more right-wing will make more mistakes at the Stroop task in the threat (vs. control) condition than people higher in left-wing political orientation.

question2a.value: For both H3a and H3b: We expect a significant difference between threat and control conditions among right-wing people, but not among left-wing. We expect that the level on DVs will be different between right- and left-wing participants in the threat condition, but not in the control condition, cf. Figure 1.

question3a.value:
The induced threat (vs. control) will be pretested, measuring if people perceive a higher risk of terrorist attack under threat (vs. control) condition. 
A manipulation check will be present after the Stroop task, asking participants to recall the topic of the presented video (terrorism v. political analysis ) or radio clip (terrorism v. municipal elections).

question5a.value: Although cognitive load induced by stereotype threat has been well documented, the possible cognitive load following a social identity threat is still understudied. In fact, coping with a stereotype threat impairs self-control and attentional processes (e.g., Inzlicht & Kang, 2010), suggesting an implication of threat on cognitive resources. However, some research (e.g., in TMT field) also suggest that social threat could provoke heightened cognitive attentional processes (see Jonas et al., 2014). Considering these studies, increase in attention seems to appear only towards related stimuli. For example,  DeWall, Maner and Rouby (2009) found an increase in attentional processes regarding smiley faces, a social cue of emotions, following a group’s social exclusion. As such, we hypothesized that, to cope with a social identity threat, people consume cognitive resources, resulting in a decrease of cognitive abilities on an unrelated cognitive task.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: Explorative analyses will comprise the test of potential order effects, the induction of positive affect and reduction of anger as potential mediators, as well as alternative test frameworks (hierarchical linear models).

sample.value: We performed an a priori power analysis (see OSF project for details). Accordingly, we aim to collect data from at least 70 participants.

analyses.value: The main hypothesis will be tested by averaging the aggression scores and submitting the compound aggression measure as the dependent variable to a paired t test (independent variable: funny video vs. control video).

outliers.value: We will conduct a debriefing interview in which participants will be probed for suspicion of the underlying hypothesis. A participant's data will be excluded from analyses if a) he or she makes a connection between the content of the videos and the measurement of aggression, b) suspects the frustrating tasks were intended to make him or her angry, c) identifies the assignment of items to the alleged other participant as an aggression measure.

dependent.value: Aggressive behavior as measured by the number of difficult items (number sequences and anagrams) assigned to an alleged other (and unknown) participant.

conditions.value:
The experiment makes use of a repeated measures design. All participants will be angered two times by means of a frustrating task (unsolvable number sequences and anagrams). After each frustrating task, they will be exposed to either a) a funny video or b) a neutral video. After each video, aggressive behavior will be measured.
Every participant will work on both tasks and watch both the funny and the neutral video. Order of tasks (anagrams first vs. number sequences first) and order of video (funny first vs. neutral first) will be counterbalanced.

hypothesis.value: Angered individuals should display less aggressive behavior after watching a humorous video clip, compared to angered individuals who subsequently watched a neutral (control) video clip.

attributes.title: Comparison classes for vague language understanding

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Comparison class inference -- adjective endorsement complementary task

other.value: For the full Bayesian data analysis model, we model the prior distribution over comparison classes by assuming a logistic function that encodes a basic-level bias as an intercept and an effect of frequency of the NP in a corpus (the Google WebGram corpus). Since our item_sets come from a group of participants and are quite heterogeneous, we do not know whether the specific NP used is a basic level or subordinate level category (i.e., should the basic-level bias make the specific comparison class more likely or less likely?). Thus, we treat the sub-basic vs. basic-super status of the items as an unknown bernoulli variable that we infer on an item_set basis (e.g., basketball players, soccer players, gymnasts as instance of people; the specific NPs would likely be subordinate categories, whereas the general NP [people] would be a basic level category; dogs, fish, and birds would be instances of animals; the specific NPs would likely be basic level categories). We evaluate the full comparison class RSA model by looking at its ability to predict the observed comparison class inference data and the adjective endorsement data (i.e., a posterior predictive check).

sample.value:
We will collect data until we have n=300 participants after exclusion criteria are applied (comprehension check, memory check, native language). This number was arrived at with the goal of getting approximately 50 responses per item on average.

In order to get finer-grained measurements for items with a lot of variability, we will do a preliminary analysis of responses after 35 measurements have been collected for each item. At this point, we will cease collecting data on items that receive the same response type (specific vs. general) on greater than or equal to 33 out of the 35 measurements. 

The experiment contains a total of 90 item sets, each containing 3 specific NPs and 2 adjectives. Thus, there are 540 unique items in this experiment, and we aim for a total of 27,000 ratings (50 per item). Each participant completes 48 trials (2 judgments per trial), so this number will require roughly 300 participants.

analyses.value:
This primary purposes of this experiment is to provide quantitative data to test a computational model of comparison class inference. We define a model in the Rational Speech Act (RSA) framework to predict comparison class inferences that we measured in a different experiment (https://osf.io/xuc96). The model makes inferences dependent on prior knowledge about categories, which we model as gaussian distributions with mean and variances that we infer using Bayesian inference. The parameters over the prior knowledge are constrained by another RSA model using the same prior knowledge to predict behavior on this adjective endorsement task. Finally, the comparison class inference model predictions depend upon a prior distribution over comparison classes.  (for more details, see final comments of this preregistration report)

As a confirmatory test, we hypothesize that positive-form adjectives (e.g., tall) will be endorsed more when they are describing members of categories that are expected to fall near the high-end of the degree scale (e.g, basketball players) and that negative-form adjectives (e.g., short) will be endorsed more when they are describing members of categories that are expected to fall near the low of the degree scale (e.g., gymnasts). This should manifest as two significant interactions with the control categories that tend to fall near the middle of the degree scale (e.g., soccer players). 

In lmer/brm syntax, the model is:

brm(
 adj_endorsement ~ np_expectations * adjective_polarity_effect + 
    (1 +  np_expectations*adjective_polarity_effect | participant) + 
    (1 +  np_expectations*adjective_polarity_effect | item_set),
  family = bernoulli()
)

adj_endorsement is a binary variable: whether or not the adjective is endosrement.

np_expectations is the general expectations about the category. It has three levels: low, medium, and high. It is dummy coded with the medium as the base level (so the predictors are deviations from the middle category)

adjective_polarity_effect is an effect-coded variable representing the contrasts of the polarity of the adjectives. adjective_polarity has two levels: negative (e.g., short), positive (e.g., tall). adjective_polarity_effect is effect coded with negative adjective having a weight of -0.5 and positive adjectives having a weight of 0.5

item_set consistents of a unique combination of three levels of np_expectations paired with a particular superordinate/general category and a degree scale (e.g., basketball players, soccer players, gymnasts; all people; degree = height).

We predict two significant interactions:

np_expectations=negative x adjective_polarity_contrast
np_expectations=positive x adjective_polarity_contrast

outliers.value:
At the start of the experiment, we employ a simple language test to rule out bots from doing our task. Participants read a short dialogue where a named speaker (e.g., Alice) talks to a named listener (e.g., Bob) about the weather. Participants must then type in a box to whom the speaker is talking (i.e., Bob). Actual names are randomly sampled frmo a list of common nanmes. Maximally three attempts are possible. Participants who fail this trial are not allow to continue to the main experiment.

In addition, the experiment ends with a memory check used for basis of exclusion. 

The memory check appears after the main trials and asks participants to “select all of the things that you can remember seeing in this experiment”. The response format is a list of 10 check-boxes: items appear next to them as adjective--noun pairs (e.g., “tall basketball player”). The list contain 5 items the participant saw and 5 distractor items that use adjectives and nouns that do not appear in any experiment (e.g., “beautiful watch”). Participants who answer correctly (HITS + CORRECT REJECTIONS) to less than 7 of the 10 items (6 or fewer) will be excluded.

Participants who self-report a native language other than English will be excluded from the analyses.

dependent.value:
Participants are asked to imagine a referent (e.g., a basketball player) and judge whether or not they believe an adjective would be true of that referent. For example, “Imagine you see a baskbetball player. Do you think they would be tall relative to the other people?”

Participants are always given an explicit comparison class (e.g., “relative to other people”) and are asked to judge both the positive-form and negative-form adjectives (e.g., “tall” and “short”). Participants can respond to the questions independently. That is, they can rate that the referent could be tall, short, neither tall nor short, or both tall and short.

conditions.value:
There are six within-participant conditions in this experiment. The six conditions come from three levels of categories crossed with two adjectives. The three levels of categories are those that are expected to fall near the high-end, low-end, and intermediate-range of the adjective degree scale (e.g., basketball players, gymnasts, and soccer players are expected to fall on the high, low, and intermediate range of the height scale). These are crossed with two adjective forms: a positive adjective (e.g., “tall”) and a negative adjective (e.g. “short”), which are judged on each trial.

Each participant completes 16 judgments (of each adjective; 32 judgments total) of the 3 category types, for a total of 48 trials.

hypothesis.value: How do human listeners adjust the comparison class when understanding scalar adjectives? [This is a norming-style experiment to rate the stimuli used in a related experiment.]

Thus, there are 540 unique items in this experiment, and we aim for a total of 27,000 ratings (50 per item). Each participant completes 48 trials (2 judgments per trial), so this number will require roughly 300 participants.
registration_responses.analyses:
This primary purposes of this experiment is to provide quantitative data to test a computational model of comparison class inference. We define a model in the Rational Speech Act (RSA) framework to predict comparison class inferences that we measured in a different experiment (https://osf.io/xuc96). The model makes inferences dependent on prior knowledge about categories, which we model as gaussian distributions with mean and variances that we infer using Bayesian inference. The parameters over the prior knowledge are constrained by another RSA model using the same prior knowledge to predict behavior on this adjective endorsement task. Finally, the comparison class inference model predictions depend upon a prior distribution over comparison classes.  (for more details, see final comments of this preregistration report)

As a confirmatory test, we hypothesize that positive-form adjectives (e.g., tall) will be endorsed more when they are describing members of categories that are expected to fall near the high-end of the degree scale (e.g, basketball players) and that negative-form adjectives (e.g., short) will be endorsed more when they are describing members of categories that are expected to fall near the low of the degree scale (e.g., gymnasts). This should manifest as two significant interactions with the control categories that tend to fall near the middle of the degree scale (e.g., soccer players). 

In lmer/brm syntax, the model is:

brm(
 adj_endorsement ~ np_expectations * adjective_polarity_effect + 
    (1 +  np_expectations*adjective_polarity_effect | participant) + 
    (1 +  np_expectations*adjective_polarity_effect | item_set),
  family = bernoulli()
)

adj_endorsement is a binary variable: whether or not the adjective is endosrement.

np_expectations is the general expectations about the category. It has three levels: low, medium, and high. It is dummy coded with the medium as the base level (so the predictors are deviations from the middle category)

adjective_polarity_effect is an effect-coded variable representing the contrasts of the polarity of the adjectives. adjective_polarity has two levels: negative (e.g., short), positive (e.g., tall). adjective_polarity_effect is effect coded with negative adjective having a weight of -0.5 and positive adjectives having a weight of 0.5

item_set consistents of a unique combination of three levels of np_expectations paired with a particular superordinate/general category and a degree scale (e.g., basketball players, soccer players, gymnasts; all people; degree = height).

We predict two significant interactions:

np_expectations=negative x adjective_polarity_contrast
np_expectations=positive x adjective_polarity_contrast
registration_responses.outliers:
At the start of the experiment, we employ a simple language test to rule out bots from doing our task. Participants read a short dialogue where a named speaker (e.g., Alice) talks to a named listener (e.g., Bob) about the weather. Participants must then type in a box to whom the speaker is talking (i.e., Bob). Actual names are randomly sampled frmo a list of common nanmes. Maximally three attempts are possible. Participants who fail this trial are not allow to continue to the main experiment.

In addition, the experiment ends with a memory check used for basis of exclusion. 

The memory check appears after the main trials and asks participants to “select all of the things that you can remember seeing in this experiment”. The response format is a list of 10 check-boxes: items appear next to them as adjective--noun pairs (e.g., “tall basketball player”). The list contain 5 items the participant saw and 5 distractor items that use adjectives and nouns that do not appear in any experiment (e.g., “beautiful watch”). Participants who answer correctly (HITS + CORRECT REJECTIONS) to less than 7 of the 10 items (6 or fewer) will be excluded.

Participants who self-report a native language other than English will be excluded from the analyses.
registration_responses.dependent:
Participants are asked to imagine a referent (e.g., a basketball player) and judge whether or not they believe an adjective would be true of that referent. For example, “Imagine you see a baskbetball player. Do you think they would be tall relative to the other people?”

Participants are always given an explicit comparison class (e.g., “relative to other people”) and are asked to judge both the positive-form and negative-form adjectives (e.g., “tall” and “short”). Participants can respond to the questions independently. That is, they can rate that the referent could be tall, short, neither tall nor short, or both tall and short.
registration_responses.conditions:
There are six within-participant conditions in this experiment. The six conditions come from three levels of categories crossed with two adjectives. The three levels of categories are those that are expected to fall near the high-end, low-end, and intermediate-range of the adjective degree scale (e.g., basketball players, gymnasts, and soccer players are expected to fall on the high, low, and intermediate range of the height scale). These are crossed with two adjective forms: a positive adjective (e.g., “tall”) and a negative adjective (e.g. “short”), which are judged on each trial.

Each participant completes 16 judgments (of each adjective; 32 judgments total) of the 3 category types, for a total of 48 trials.
registration_responses.hypothesis: How do human listeners adjust the comparison class when understanding scalar adjectives? [This is a norming-style experiment to rate the stimuli used in a related experiment.]

name.value: Spatial navigation and facial recognition: Experiment 2

other.value:
We may look at whether number of years in Canada/US affected individuals' performance/scores (i.e., as a proxy of comprehension), as well as whether individuals report having any neurological impairments. We will also look at whether familiarity with the building in the video played affected their navigation accuracy overall. We will also be examining whether performance on the cognitive tasks varied as a function of individual differences factors (i.e., age, gender, ethnicity)

Although we have started data collection (so far, only 12/200 participants' data have been collected), we have not conducted any analyses on the data set so far.

sample.value: We would like to collect data from a minimum of 200 participants.

analyses.value:
We will be replicating the results described above. 

In addition, we will also examine how accurately people are at recognizing target vs foil objects to ensure that they are paying attention in the video.

outliers.value: We will be excluding participants who do not report having normal/corrected to normal vision. For the analysis, we may exclude participants who do not score above 80% for the mental rotation task for trials where the items are rotated at 0 degrees and are identical (i.e., an attention check). We will also exclude participants who admitted that they were not paying attention or trying to complete the task properly for that debrief question.

dependent.value:
Cambridge face memory task (Duchaine & Nakayama, 2006)
Mental spatial rotation task (Ganis & Kievit, 2014)
Navigation tasks:
-Route Recall Task: We will show participants a recording of a walking route around the building and have them recall the route they took on a map
-Landmark Position Task: we will ask participants to select where the distinctive items (landmarks) in the video walking route were given a different position along the route. In this experiment, participants will also asked to differentiate between target and foil items prior to this task. 

We additionally will be asking participants to provide their age, gender, ethnicity, and if they have corrected to normal vision. 

At the end of the experiment, we will be asking participants if they had any issues with the study, if they were familiar with the building the video walking route was of, and if they completed the experiment to the best of their abilities.

conditions.value: All participants will complete the same version of this study. There are no experimental conditions.

hypothesis.value:
In a previous experiment, we examined the relation between facial recognition ability (i.e., using the Cambridge face memory task) and spatial/navigational abilities using the following tasks:
1. Wayfinding questionnaire (WQ)
2. Route recall task (RCT) where participants indicated the route they saw in a video
3. Landmark position task (LPT) where participants indicated, using a protractor, what angle any given target objects they encountered were from a location along the route they passed

We also included a mental spatial rotation task (MSRT), to test the idea that it may underlie or explain the relation between spatial navigation and facial recognition ability.

In examining the correlation between each of the tasks, the spatial navigation tasks/questionnaires indicated no correlation between each other, except for between the WQ and the LPT. 

For the relation between face processing and spatial navigation ability, we found that the CFMT was only correlated with the LPT. Further, the CMFT also correlated with the MSRT. 

We then conducted a hierarchical linear regression to further explore these relations, using CMFT as the dependent variable and the MSRT and LPT, as well as their interaction term, as predictors. We found that the LPT was a significant predictor of CMFT, and this relation was moderated by MR. 

The aim of the current experiment is to replicate these results.
